title: 110_hr4916
content: The Act may be cited as the "Aeronautics and Space Prize Act". It establishes the National Endowment for Aeronautics and Space. The National Endowment for Aeronautics and Space (referred to as the "Endowment") is established for the purpose of awarding cash prizes for outstanding achievements in research, technology development, and prototype demonstration related to aeronautics and space endeavors. Additionally, it carries out a program for advertising commercial products and services in collaboration with NASA and other agencies. The National Endowment for Aeronautics and Space is established to award cash prizes for achievements in aeronautics and space research, technology development, and prototype demonstration. It also promotes commercial products and services in collaboration with NASA and other agencies, and encourages private donations for the benefit of aeronautics and space endeavors. The Endowment has the authority to create rules and regulations for its operations. The National Endowment for Aeronautics and Space has the power to appoint officers, employees, and advisory committees, as well as enter into contracts and grants for lawful acts necessary for its purposes. The National Endowment for Aeronautics and Space can utilize NASA and other Federal agencies' services without reimbursement. It can also accept gifts, devises, or bequests for the benefit of the Nation's aeronautics and space endeavors within NASA. The National Endowment for Aeronautics and Space can accept gifts, devises, or bequests for the benefit of NASA and other governmental agencies involved in aeronautics and space endeavors within the United States, including real property interests for public preservation and conservation. The Endowment is limited in accepting gifts that entail any expenditure other than specified purposes. The National Endowment for Aeronautics and Space can accept gifts, devises, or bequests for the benefit of NASA and other governmental agencies involved in aeronautics and space endeavors within the United States. Property transferred to the Endowment is considered contributions to the United States. The Endowment must report its activities annually to Congress. The Chairperson of the Endowment is appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate. The Chairperson of the National Endowment for Aeronautics and Space is responsible for exercising all powers and duties of the Endowment, with authority over personnel and activities. The Chairperson serves a 4-year term, can be reappointed, and must align Endowment programs with other groups. The Chairperson of the National Endowment for Aeronautics and Space can collaborate with other Federal agencies to support aeronautics and space activities through interagency agreements using authorized funds. SEC. 3. NATIONAL ADVANCED SPACE AND AERONAUTICAL TECHNOLOGIES PRIZE AWARD PROGRAM. The Endowment will carry out a program described in section 2(b)(1) and will advertise prize competitions using a competitive process. Recipients of prizes must register for the competition. Under the program established, participants must waive claims against the US Government for any injury, death, or loss arising from competition participation. The term "related entity" includes contractors, subcontractors, suppliers, customers, and grantees. Limitations apply to the total amount of cash prizes budgeted. The program sets a limit of $150,000,000 for cash prizes in a fiscal year, with no single prize exceeding $50,000 without approval. Funds remain available for up to 4 years, and a report on prize administration is required annually. The cash prizes awarded for aeronautics and space applications totaled $150,000,000 annually, with no single prize exceeding $50,000 without approval. The methods for solicitation and evaluation of submissions were assessed for effectiveness. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out this Act.
